summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, prohibiting courtroom sketch artists from drawing exact likenesses of certain witnesses who are permitted to testify using pseudonyms or first names. The order aims to protect the identities of these 'Protected Witnesses'.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (S2 20 Cr. 330) for which this protective order is issued.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge who issued the proposed order to protect witness identities by restricting courtroom sketch artists.

events.title: Court Order on Witness Pseudonyms
events.description: The court ordered that certain witnesses would be permitted to testify using pseudonyms or only first names.

events.title: Order Restricting Courtroom Sketches
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order prohibiting courtroom sketch artists from drawing exact likenesses of the Protected Witnesses.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court has designated certain witnesses as 'Protected Witnesses' who can testify using pseudonyms or first names.
Courtroom sketch artists are explicitly prohibited from drawing exact likenesses of these Protected Witnesses.
The order applies to sketch artists in both the main courtroom and overflow rooms.
Sketch artists may consult with the court or counsel to determine if a witness is protected.
This document is part of the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (S2 20 Cr. 330).
